Prerequisites

We recommend that readers consult the sections Understanding text and First steps to gain a deeper understanding of the summarized information presented in this text (History Tracers Team. Understanding text ; History Tracers Team. First steps).

Introduction

The expanse of human knowledge is vast, and when bringing it into the classroom, it's necessary to curate specific elements that offer students a comprehensive understanding. Nevertheless, this doesn't discourage students from delving deeper and broadening their perspectives. To assist individuals on this journey, this segment of History Tracers presents insights into diverse cultures throughout history, organized within common historical epochs. Our aim is to showcase the evolution of humanity across different continents and epochs.

This section of History Tracers draws inspiration from the works of Roberto Moras (Moras, Roberto, America: Lo que no te contaron), Cy (Cy, History with Cy) and Yuval Noah Harari (Harari, Yuval Noah, Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind).

Like any Science, History is also directly connected to the language of mathematics. For this reason, we begin this section with Chapter 6 of the First Steps, which is dedicated to the study of mathematics in connection with other sciences. Thus, we recommend reading the first five chapters of that part before continuing (History Tracers Team, First Steps).

Although in school we are introduced to subjects called Science or History before entering university, teaching often limits itself to presenting only the initial stages of this field. These stages could be referred to as proto-History or pre-History, as proposed by Dr. Francisco González A. Redondo (González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; History Tracers Team, The knowledge).

In the texts of this section, we present the concepts of pre-History and proto-History, gradually connecting them to History through mathematics.
Chapter 1: To be or not to be...

value.name: On Equality
value.desc: In this text, we begin exploring the concept of comparison and the methods for grouping identical objects.

value.name: Equality Levels
value.desc: Some concepts, like the definition of a planet, change over time. Sometimes, objects with slightly different sizes can be considered equal. How can we use numbers to quantify equality?

value.name: Are we truly equal?
value.desc: In this text, we explore the acceptable limits of inequality and emphasize that within our species, there are no races.

value.name: Bigger or Smaller
value.desc: Concluding the comparisons, we analyze the relationship between objects by classifying them as bigger or smaller.

value.name: Shared Origin
value.desc: After observing different ways of grouping and counting quantities, we moved on to studying the sharing of those quantities.

value.name: Simplicity vs. Complexity
value.desc: Despite more than 13.8 billion years of evolution of the universe, we often still wish to be like it was in its beginnings. Why?

value.name: Two sides
value.desc: good and evil, left and right, matter and energy, up and down. Is this duality enough?

value.name: Expanding...
value.desc: Continuing from the previous text, we see that dividing into just two sides ends up doing omissions

value.name: Always present
value.desc: many times we are so focused on ourselves or on opposites that we do not notice what is always present.

value.name: Evolution of Knowledge: The Atom
value.desc: In this text, we study how our idea of the atom has evolved over time.

value.name: The four divisions
value.desc: in addition to the four limbs of the human body, the number four has also been used in various contexts throughout the history of humanity.

value.name: Dividing again
value.desc: When we perform a division, we can repeat it — but how can we represent this idea in the language of mathematics?

value.name: Evolution of knowledge – The hydrogen atom
value.desc: Hydrogen is the smallest atom we know of; even so, inside it we can still find other particles.

value.name: Is this extra?
value.desc: In this text, we introduce the concept of a remainder in division.

value.name: Returning
value.desc: In this text, we present the subtraction operation as a form of return.

value.name: Cooking
value.desc: The preparation of food is often remembered for adding quantities, but there is also another side to it.

value.name: Practicing subtraction
value.desc: In this text, the reader is introduced to an application that generates random subtraction problems with descriptions of the calculation steps.

value.name: The Difference of Equals
value.desc: In this text, we study the mathematical operation that allows us to determine whether something is equal or not.

value.name: Nearly identical
value.desc: As atoms were generated in nature, some of them ended up so similar that we cannot tell them apart.

value.name: There is something else
value.desc: In this text, we return to the kitchen to check how much is left of the ingredients from a recipe.

value.name: Organizing time
value.desc: Many cultures organize time into 7-day weeks and months with varying numbers of days (28/29, 30, or 31). Is this division accurate?

value.name: Divisions and remainders
value.desc: In this text, we create an application that helps readers practice division step by step.

value.name: Together we are strong
value.desc: In this text, we see how the four operations, when combined, open the doors to so much knowledge

content.html_value: Chapter 4: Time (A Physics variable in History)

value.name: What is time?
value.desc: In this text, we begin to explore one of the most important variables in both history and physics—time.

value.name: Chronology
value.desc: Is it possible to create a universal timeline applicable to all of humanity?

value.name: Origin
value.desc: How many generations do we have?

value.name: Culture and Civilization
value.desc: Is there a hierarchy between them?

value.name: Cradles of civilization (Part I)
value.desc: While humanity originated in Africa, the first civilizations emerged in various regions around the world, such as Mesopotamia, the Andes, and Mesoamerica.

value.name: Cradles of civilization (Parte II)
value.desc: We continue our study by exploring the civilizations of Egypt, Indus Valley, and China.

value.name: Sumerian King List
value.desc: This text compiles all references to the Sumerian King List available in History Tracers.
